Title: Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy for Live Cell Imaging
Description: The University of Newcastle aims to develop its state-of-the-art facility in Live Cell Confocal Laser Scanning Microscopy to complement its existing expertise in imaging, comparative proteomics and genomic cellular analysis. With this facility in place we shall be in a unique and powerful position to identify and characterize targeted populations of cells in a range of projects from male germ cell development to plant biotechnology. The purchase of a new generation laser scanning confocal microscope will also provide critical support to a highly productive priority research and research training nexus at the University that is associated with two ARC Centres of Excellence.
Investigators: Prof KT Jones; Dr EA McLaughlin; Prof RJ Aitken; Prof RJ Rose; Em/Prof JW Patrick; Adj/Prof CE Offler; A/Prof DW McCurdy; Prof LK Ashman; Prof GF Burns; A/Prof DF van Helden; Dr NM Verrills; Dr B Nixon; Dr SD Roman; A/Prof Y Ruan; Dr RF Thorne; Prof MB Calford

Title: An Advanced Mass Spectrometry Facility for Applications in Proteomics and Organic Chemistry
Description: The Advanced Mass Spectrometry Unit possesses a Linear Ion Trap mass spectrometer, which is heavily used for conducting proteomic analyses.   This instrument, initially purchased in 2005, has established Newcastle as a leading centre for proteomics research (4 papers in 'Proteomics' in 2007). However, if we are to retain this position we need an instrument with greater accuracy, sensitivity and versatility.  The latter is particularly important because there is high demand for improved facilities to isolate and characterize organic compounds in the context of 'metabolomics', forensic science, natural products, medicinal chemistry, biosensor development and organic electronics.
Investigators: Prof RJ Aitken; A/Prof A McCluskey; Dr MA Baker; Dr NM Verrills; A/Prof M Maeder; Dr X Zhou; Dr EA McLaughlin; Dr B Nixon; Dr SD Roman; Prof RJ Rose; A/Prof RH Dunstan; Prof CP Grof; Prof R Smith; Prof P Gibson; Prof AL Jones; Prof MB Calford; Prof KT Jones; Dr RF Thorne; Prof PR Dunkley; Prof PS Foster; Prof LK Ashman; Prof GF Burns; Dr PW Dickson; Prof JA Rostas; Prof RJ Scott; Dr PA Tooney; A/Prof PM Hansbro; A/Prof PA Moscato; A/Prof PC Dastoor; Dr PJ Lewis; Dr P Stanton; A/Prof DM Robertson

Title: Electron Microscopes for Nanometer-Scale Imaging/Microanalysis in the Materials, Biological, Physical, Engineering and Chemical Sciences
Description: Electron microscope imaging and microanalysis on nanometre scales is central to research in the materials, physical, chemical, earth, life and medical sciences and a broad range of engineering disciplines. Our current electron microscopes are grossly inadequate for the needs of the large and diverse user community. This proposal seeks to provide researchers in the Newcastle, Hunter, Central and Lower North Coast regions with state-of-the-art nano-scale imaging and microanalysis via the acquisition of a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope and a 200kV analytical Transmission Electron Microscope. These will directly benefit a broad spectrum of research across the University of Newcastle and within its industrial partners.
Investigators: Prof EH Kisi; Dr SW Donne; Dr VJ Keast; A/Prof AM Brichta; Prof RE Melchers; Adj/Prof CE Offler; Prof J O'Connor; Prof SO Moheimani; Em/Prof JW Patrick; A/Prof DF van Helden; A/Prof BV King; Prof GM Evans; A/Prof RH Dunstan; Dr GR MacFarlane; A/Prof Y Ruan; Dr SM Roselli; Dr M Lin; Prof CP Grof; Dr S Frisia; Dr R Lim; Dr HO Sugo; Dr JS Forrester; Dr OP Buzzi; Dr AJ Fleming; A/Prof EJ Wanless; Dr CI Holdsworth; Dr RN Drysdale; A/Prof SG Fityus; A/Prof DW McCurdy; Dr D Zhu; Dr CJ Fell; Prof B Moghtaderi; Dr AJ McFarlane; Dr PJ Lewis

Title: Developing the Helium Atom Pinhole Camera
Description: This project aims to develop a unique new instrument for nanotechnology based on the use of a helium atom beam. Due to their extremely low energy and wave-particle nature, helium atoms offer the possibility of a uniquely sensitive, non-perturbing probe of delicate soft polymer surfaces with potentially sub-nanometre resolution. This proposal seeks to exploit Cambridge University's expertise in helium beam imaging by allowing the ARCIF to help develop two key elements of the new atom microscope currently under construction at Newcastle. This proposal will greatly enhance the development and characterization of the atom source and detection systems that are critical to the performance of the new atom microscope.
Investigators: A/Prof PC Dastoor; Dr W Allison

Title: Pharmaceutical Promotion: Productive or Problematic?
Description: New medical technologies are both productive and problematic for public health - while many will improve individual and public health they will also divert attention from non-medical interventions, sometimes result in poorer health outcomes due to adverse effects, and capture an increasing share of national and household health budgets. Managing the demand for new treatments is a task exacerbated by the commercial nature of pharmaceutical development and dissemination. One key commercial aspect, pharmaceutical promotion, is becoming more common, more publicly directed and more potentially problematic. This project aims to establish the degree to which promotion is prevalent and problematic in Australia
Investigators: Dr E Doran; Prof D Henry; Mr RN Moynihan

Title: Integrated Surface Fabrication and Characterisation Laboratory
Description: The study of thin film devices from polymers and organic molecules is one of the most rapidly developing research areas in Australia and typically involves fabricating structures under controlled environments. Although electron spectroscopy is essential for characterizing the chemical and electronic properties of these delicate materials there is currently no facility in Australia capable of fabricating and characterising these fragile materials in the same system. The IntLAB facility combines an inert atmosphere glovebox with an electron spectroscopy analysis system to produce a versatile facility that can be used to fabricate and characterise thin films without exposure to the external environment.
Investigators: A/Prof PC Dastoor; Prof J O'Connor; A/Prof BV King; A/Prof A McCluskey; Dr WJ Belcher; Prof CM Stampfl; Dr JR Reimers; A/Prof AR Hamilton; Dr AP Micolich; Dr CJ Fell; Dr SE Watkins; Dr M Bown; Dr AP Stampfl; Dr PJ Evans

Title: Ring Current and Radiation Belt Dynamics
Description: The magnetosphere region of near-Earth space includes the highly energetic Van Allen radiation belts, medium energy ring current and the cold ambient plasmasphere.  These regions are dynamic, complex and non-linear and support a variety of wave-particle interactions which contribute to ring current decay and radiation belt particle losses.  The electromagnetic ion cyclotron wave contribution to these interactions will be quantified using a combined observational and modelling approach based on international collaboration.  This will contribute to our further understanding of weather in space and provide access to satellite data and modelling simulations not currently available in Australia.
Investigators: Prof BJ Fraser; Dr CC Chaston; Dr HJ Singer

Title: Aboriginal identities within architecture and the built environment: Perceptions of a sample of Indigenous and non-Indigenous architects
Description: This is a qualitative research project that is based on the Indigenous Research Methodology of 'reframing' (Smith, 1999: 153-4) to present an Indigenous perspective. It is the first time that Indigenous architect's voices have been brought together in a form that will engage and benefit those in the emerging field of Indigenous architecture, where their voices and experiences have hitherto been marginalised. There are very few Indigenous architects in Australia and this is an opportunity to present their voices and experiences. The ultimate outcome is a Master of Philosophy.
Investigators: Ms TS Mallie; Asst Prof NA Blair; Dr S Fleming

Title: Analysis of the effectiveness of a Quality Teaching framework in increasing Aboriginal students' educational outcomes
Description: The aim of this project is to analyse the effectiveness of the NSW Quality Teaching framework in increasing educational outcomes for Aboriginal students. The NSW Quality Teaching framework will be compared to Aboriginal pedagogical models to discern the similarities between these structures that contribute to successful outcomes for Aboriginal students. This research will identify teaching practices that support Indigenous styles of learning and will result in academic publications as well as pedagogical materials for use in schools and Indigenous communities.
Investigators: Mr M Donovan

Title: Shaping social and cultural spaces: the application of computer visualisation and machine learning techniques to the design of architectural and urban spaces
Description: The built environment represents a significant cultural and social investment in Australia's future. Its success depends on the ability of designers to create spaces that can accommodate increasing urban density. Conventional theory for the creation of such spaces relies on a range of historic concepts. Yet, modern architectural and urban space is more complex technically, culturally and socially than ever before.   Computer technology developed for the robotics industry provides a previously unavailable tool for understanding and designing complex spaces. This project is a world-first combining architectural theory, machine learning and computational analysis for assisting the design of socially and culturally responsive environments.
Investigators: Prof MJ Ostwald; Dr SK Chalup

Title: The Dynamics of Plant Cell Division-Discovering the Mechanisms of Organelle Inheritance
Description: Cell division is essential to the growth of all life forms. Organelles are essential cell components and thus continued cell division requires that each daughter cell inherit these organelles. In plants, partitioning of organelles between daughter cells is an actin cytoskeleton dependent event. However, the molecular mechanisms of organelle partitioning and the processes that ensure intactness of organelle genomes are unknown. This project will use new approaches to discover key genes involved in organelle partitioning and will elucidate the mechanisms that maintain organelle genomes. Outcomes will contribute to new knowledge of plant cell dynamics relevant to plant biotechnology and foster a high calibre research-training environment.
Investigators: Mr MB Sheahan

Title: Dynamical systems and iterative decoding of low-density parity-check codes
Description: Modern communications is based on the premise that information represented digitally can be reliably transmitted, stored and reproduced. After some 50 years of steady progress in designing the error control codes needed to ensure integrity of data transmission and storage, breakthroughs in the late-1990s have used principles of iteration and feedback to push the theoretically achievable performance of low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes close to fundamental limits, though practical codes fall short of these limits. This project aims to apply techniques from the theory of nonlinear dynamical systems to analyse and design practical iterative decoding algorithms for next-generation digital communications based on LDPC codes.
Investigators: Dr SR Weller; Dr CM Kellett

Title: Modelling of Damage Progression and its Effects on the Expected Safety and Satisfactory Performance of Existing Reinforced Concrete Infrastructure
Description: The project deals with the effects that accumulated and combined damages, such as cracking, spalling, reinforcement corrosion bond loss can have on the continued safety and reliability of the structural performance of reinforced concrete infrastructure.  The particular focus in this project is existing infrastructure. It will develop stochastic deterioration models that describe progression of damage, and extend the modelling to allow for maintenance actions and spatial variability in  structural response. New techniques will be developed to incorporate these models in procedures for time-dependent structural reliability analysis. The outcomes will enhance engineering risk assessment for infrastructure decision-making.
Investigators: Prof RE Melchers; Prof MG Stewart

Title: Endomorphisms, transfer operators and Hilbert modules
Description: We propose to study actions of semigroups by endomorphisms of operator algebras, focusing on ways of representing the components by bounded linear operators on Hilbert space. The emphasis will be on actions which are not invertible, and the approach is motivated by interesting examples arising in a variety of areas. The key examples arise from irreversible dynamics, the higher-rank analogues of directed graphs, and actions underlying the theory of multi-resolution analyses in Hilbert modules. Our main techniques will be those of functional analysis, especially those of operator-algebraic representation theory, but we also plan to adopt some more unusual techniques from abstract algebra.
Investigators: Prof I Raeburn; Dr A an Huef

Title: Modelling of Bypass Pneumatic Conveying Systems
Description: Pneumatic conveying is widely used throughout the process industry as an efficient and cost effective method of transporting particulate solids. The lower velocities in dense phase conveying reduce attrition of the conveyed material; minimise erosive wear, and hence maintenance, of pipelines; and significantly lower energy requirements. However, many materials can not be conveyed in dense phase in conventional pipelines.  This project will deliver new, experimentally validated models to predict the operation of bypass pneumatic conveying pipelines and enable a range of bulk solids to be conveyed in dense phase that previously could not.
Investigators: Prof MG Jones

Title: Influence of adsorbed surfactants on three phase contact line motion at high capillary number
Description: This project is aimed at increasing our understanding of wetting/dewetting phenomena at Capillary numbers relevant to a number of industrial processes and beyond which existing theories are applicable. The research will focus on hydrodynamic and molecular interactions, and use a combination of numerical modelling and experimental measurement to predict the dynamic interaction between moving films and solid surfaces. The presence of adsorbed surfactants on the motion of the three phase contact line will also be included. The research is particularly relevant to industrial coating operations and mineral flotation.
Investigators: Mr CM Phan

Title: Partner training and communication outcomes for students with multiple and severe disabilities
Description: Students with multiple and severe disabilities (MSD) have extremely low levels of communication and interaction. Their communication is typically not measureable through standard assessments. However, previous research by the applicants suggests that (a) communicative involvement is assessable, and (b) contextual factors impact on the level of communicative involvement. This study investigates whether targeted training of communication partners produces quantifiable improvements in behaviour states and communication. We also investigate whether the impact of training varies according to the setting in which students receive their education program, and/or leads to changes in the perceived competence of communication partners.
Investigators: Prof PJ Foreman; Dr M Arthur-Kelly

Title: Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron Waves and Magnetosphere Plasma Dynamics
Description: The magnetosphere region of near-Earth space is complex non-linear and dynamic. It includes the highly energetic radiation belts, the medium energy ring current and the cold plasmasphere. These regions are connected by fundamental processes operating over wide scale ranges. Three outstanding issues will be addressed through the contribution of electromagnetic ion cyclotron (EMIC) waves to ring current decay, radiation belt relativistic electron loss and the role of heavy ions in these interactions. A combined observation and modeling approach provides a unique opportunity to quantify the ring current/radiation belt response to EMIC wave-particle interaction during geomagnetic storms and contribute to new space weather understanding.
Investigators: Prof BJ Fraser; Dr CC Chaston

Title: Supervision of psychotherapy: Understanding the processes that build professional competence
Description: Clinical supervision is the main method of assuring accountability, providing support, and preventing burn-out in mental health professionals. Yet relatively little is known about the processes of supervision and how they impact on therapist competence. This study addresses calls for systematic evaluation of clinical supervision. It involves a multi-method qualitative interview study of psychotherapy supervisor-supervisee pairs. It aims to better understand the supervisory processes that build professional competence and factors that influence supervision effectiveness. A model will be developed that links supervision processes with supervisee competence with clients; it will inform policy development, professional training and practice.
Investigators: Dr MJ Schofield; A/Prof JA Grant

Title: A framework for modelling feature variability and dependencies in software product lines
Description: There is increased pressure for the software industry to deliver higher quality software products in shorter time to market with lower costs. Software product line is a new development methodology used to solve these problems via constructive reuse of the common features among the member products in a product family. Feature modelling will identify the common features and effectively manage the varied aspects of the member products to make the product line based development feasible. This project aims to develop a framework containing several novel approaches to feature modelling to significantly improve the modelling quality. Based on the framework a prototype tool will also be implemented for the software industry to use and evaluate.
Investigators: Dr H Ye; Dr Y Lin

Title: New Approaches for Wireless Implantable Biomedical Devices
Description: The word 'implantable' in medical commonly refers to a device that is inserted or embedded through surgery and used to replace or rectify a part of the body whose physical existence or functionality has been lost. Among the wide variety of implants there is a class of implants, which perform their prosthesis through functioning of electronics using integrated circuit technology. The objective of this proposal is to develop novel technology and systems for wireless communication and power applied to such medical implants, employing radio frequency communication and optical communication schemes. This technology could help facilitate a wide range of general implants that require power and data in-vivo.
Investigators: Dr MR Yuce

Title: Efficient and Robust Prediction at Ungauged Catchments
Description: Most catchments are ungauged meaning they have no or limited streamflow records. Robust prediction at ungauged catchments by regionalisation of hydrological models has thus far eluded the hydrological sciences community. This is because the sources of uncertainty are not adequately characterised in the hydrological modelling process leading to confounding systematic errors and incorrect assessments of predictive uncertainty. This project will develop a new approach for the calibration and regionalisation of hydrological models that explicitly incorporates all the sources of uncertainty affecting prediction at ungauged basins. This will provide more accurate predictions and robust quantification of predictive uncertainty at ungauged basins.
Investigators: Prof GA Kuczera; Dr MA Thyer; A/Prof SW Franks

Title: Application of novel exact combinatorial optimisation techniques and metaheuristic methods for problems in cancer research
Description: The design and analysis of computer algorithms is vital in the challenging field of knowledge extraction from large-scale datasets coming obtained with high-throughput technologies in cancer research. Computer scientists propose new mathematical models based on combinatorial optimization. Many of these problems are deemed 'computationally intractable', yet it is imperative to address them and to provide high-quality solutions. Exact or heuristic methods have been very useful, but their hybridization brings a huge synergy. We will apply a design methodology that exploits this synergy with problem domain knowledge via hybridization of these methods and reduce the problem size without losing optimal solutions.
Investigators: Dr PA Moscato; Prof RJ Scott; Dr MA Langston

Title: Enhanced Mixing Through Particle Motion in Micro-Channels
Description: This proposal is concerned with investigating a novel, and cost-effective solution to the problem of mixing in micro-channels, which if successful could become widely adopted in a broad range of microfluidic devices with major ramifications in medical diagnostics, biotechnology, and biochemical engineering. The project examines the motion of solid particles in a micro-channel with the primary aim of establishing the extent to which the mixing of two miscible fluids in the channel can be enhanced through the motion of the particles. A range of innovative experimental and theoretical approaches will be employed to achieve the broad objectives of the project.
Investigators: A/Prof B Moghtaderi; Prof KP Galvin

Title: Automatic detection of the circle of Willis in neuro-images using multi-scale gradient calculation and knowledge-based genetic algorithms
Description: We aim to contribute to stroke prevention by developing a system which can automatically detect and quantify the circle of Willis in neuroimages by combining advanced image segmentation techniques with knowledge-based recognition techniques. Our system is novel and unique in the sense that it takes the advantages of (a) high reliability of local candidate vessel segmentation with intensity analysis and (b) high robustness of structure reasoning with knowledge-based genetic algorithms. The system can also be used in endovascular interventions, multimodal image registration and 3D visualization. It can significantly reduce the cost of treating stroke.
Investigators: Prof JS Jin; Dr S Luo; A/Prof U Schall

Title: Moral Hazard and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Description: Pharmaceutical insurance schemes, such as Australia's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, are believed to induce excess patient demand (moral hazard) resulting in inefficiency and waste. Initiatives to reduce moral hazard largely involve increases in patient cost-sharing to suppress excess demand without impacting on affordability. However, there is little direct evidence on the extent and significance of moral hazard in Australian pharmaceutical utilisation or on the effectiveness of cost sharing to reduce it. Using observational and experimental methods, this project aims to collect empirical data directly from consumers to determine the extent and significance of pharmaceutical related moral hazard
Investigators: Dr E Doran; Prof D Henry; A/Prof G Salkeld; Dr J Robertson

Title: Improving climate models through new insights on long-term inter-hemispheric climate synchronicity from speleothems
Description: A long-standing issue in palaeoclimatology is how orbitally forced climate changes are transmitted across the Earth's surface via internal feedbacks, and whether these changes occur synchronously between hemispheres. Our international team will compile new and precisely dated palaeoclimate records from speleothems in both hemispheres to determine the timing and magnitude of leads and lags in the climate system between 100,000 and 400,000 years ago. This ground-breaking research will provide new data to test palaeoclimate models and hypotheses on climate forcing. It will also generate exciting new insights on the long-term behaviour of thermohaline circulation, which is critical to Earth's climate system.
Investigators: Dr RN Drysdale; Dr JC Hellstrom; Dr R Maas; Dr G- Zanchetta; Prof AE Fallick; Prof G Lohmann

Title: Modelling and Optimisation of Belt Conveyor Systems
Description: Recent advances in belt conveying technology have resulted in the construction of longer and faster conveyor systems. Paradoxically, this has placed tremendous pressure on existing empirical design methodology. This has provided the possibility to design much better systems through the development of a better understanding of conveyor mechanics. This project is focused on this aim. Our approach to building a new foundation for conveyor design will be based on the application of advanced viscoelastic and Mohr-Coulomb continuum models to the interaction between the material, the belt and the idlers. For the first time, this will provide the opportunity to optimise belt conveyor systems in terms of both power consumption and life-cycle cost.
Investigators: Em/Prof AW Roberts; Dr CM Wensrich; Dr CA Wheeler

Title: Advancing System Identification using Modern Optimisation Methods
Description: An essential part of science, engineering and economics is the development of mathematical models to describe how certain quatities relate to one another. For example, such models have proven to be extremely powerful in predicting the value of financial instruments, and in providing high performance control of robots, and in detecting faults or changes in petrochemical processing plants. This project is directed at developing such models using modern computer based optimisation methods, but for situations that, on the one hand, have previously been considered unsolvable, and on the other, are acknowledged as being of high practical interest.
Investigators: A/Prof BM Ninness; Dr AG Wills

Title: Robust Experiment Design for Dynamical System Identification
Description: Experiment design is a pivotal component of any investigation that involves the estimation of unknown parameters of a given system. The overall goal of experiment design is to adjust the experimental conditions during data collection so that maximal information is obtained about the system in a given time period. This project is aimed at the development of new robust experiment design methodologies  and algorithms specifically targeted towards the identification of models for dynamical systems. The term robust is used here with respect to the nature and extent of the available prior knowledge we possess regarding the system.
Investigators: Dr JS Welsh; Prof GC Goodwin

Title: Role of vegetation patchiness and self organisation in the ecohydrologic response of water limited ecosystems to climate variability and change
Description: Arid and semi-arid areas constitute over 70% of the Australian continent. The runoff from these areas is characterized by extended droughts which drive the ecosystem, and constrain agriculture and other activities. The aims of this project are to improve our understanding of ecohydrologic and erosion processes in water-limited ecosystems (sub-humid to arid regions) and to develop and test a physically based ecohydrologic modelling framework to assess the impacts on hydrology and erosion of climate variability and change in those ecosystems. The understanding gained from this research can be used to establish principles for the management of semi-arid rangelands and their effect on hydrology.
Investigators: Dr PM Saco; Prof GR Willgoose; Mr DJ Tongway

Title: Models of contract law: are broad principles better than detailed rules?
Description: This project addresses a fundamental question about contract law that is relevant to all fields of law. It will test empirically the hypothesis that the law works better stated in the form of broad principles rather than detailed rules. This hypothesis is based on the results of a prior ARC project. It is controversial because it contradicts a widely held belief, shared by the current High Court of Australia, that the contrary is true. Debate on this subject has endured for over 200 years. It has hitherto been conducted in purely theoretical terms. Large claims of benefit to the law and society can be made on both sides. Our prior research supplied the first empirical data on this issue. This project will verify and extend this research.
Investigators: Prof EW Wright; A/Prof MP Ellinghaus

Title: A Fundamental Study on Redox Behaviour of Oxygen Carriers in Chemical Looping Combustion
Description: This project determines the underlying science necessary to support existing and future use of metal oxide oxygen carriers in Chemical Looping Combustion (CLC) applications. CLC with inherent ability for CO2 capture is one of several promising combustion concepts suitable for post-combustion removal of CO2 and abating greenhouse gas emissions from large stationary fossil fuel based power plants. The proposed project examines the redox behaviour of metallic oxide oxygen carriers used in CLC with the aim of gaining a more fundamental understanding about the impact of reaction conditions and structural/compositional transformations on their redox characteristics.
Investigators: A/Prof B Moghtaderi; Prof TF Wall

Title: An Integrated Multi-Node Microfluidics Facility
Description: The aim of this proposal is to establish an 'Integrated Multi-Node Microfluidics Facility' for studying micro-devices. The Facility will foster research in two complementary key areas essential in the development of novel micro-devices, namely: (i) micro fabrication and (ii) micro flow characterisation. The Facility will comprise a set of complementary equipment items which will be housed in various nodes across the collaborating institutions. The unique multi-node approach employed here will allow us to reach our common goal (i.e. microfluidic research) by making a more effective use of the expertise, facilities and resources available at participating institutions.
Investigators: A/Prof B Moghtaderi; Prof GM Evans; Prof BS Haynes; Prof AR Masri; Prof KD King; Dr ZT Alwahabi; Dr J Liow; A/Prof Y He; Prof KP Galvin; Prof BZ Dlugogorski; A/Prof EM Kennedy; Dr L Djenidi

Title: Development of a novel desalination process
Description: The project outlined in this document is concerned with developing a novel desalination process for small-scale production (< 30 m3/day) of freshwater based on the concept of humidification-dehumidification (HDH).The project examines the suitability of a range of innovative measures for incorporation into the proposed HDH process with the primary aim of establishing the extent to which the yield of freshwater can be enhanced. The proposed study consists of experimental and modelling work comprising four complementary and overlapping strands, namely: psychrometric, desalination, safety, and modelling studies.
Investigators: A/Prof B Moghtaderi; A/Prof EM Kennedy; Prof BZ Dlugogorski; Mr N Arthur

Title: Dry Processing of Fine Coal Using the Reflux Classifier
Description: The aim of this study is to investigate the potential for using the Reflux Classifier in the dry processing of fine coal. There is growing interest in dry processing because of the lack of water in many areas of Australia, especially where many of the major coal resources exist. There are also billion dollar economic advantages in ensuring the coal remains dry during its processing. The Reflux Classifier has previously been investigated using the more conventional water based approach. A shear induced lift force has been shown to selectively re-suspend and hence recover lower density particles. This effect will be studied using an air based system, with a view to establishing a new and efficient dry coal separator.
Investigators: Prof KP Galvin; A/Prof B Moghtaderi

Title: Chemical listening devices: Novel sensors targeting the clandestine manufacture and transport of illicit drugs and explosives.
Description: As Australia faces increasing threats from terrorism & drug trafficking; new approaches & strategies for border protection are required. We will develop chemical listening devices suitable for remote sensing and detection of explosives & illicit drugs, intelligence gathering, and when appropriately configured informing authorities of the presence of the targeted species at the point of entry.  Our devices will be multi-modal & in-field ready, producing characteristic drug & explosive signatures, reducing the number of false positives obtained.  We have the potential to screen every container/individual entering and leaving Australia for chemical residues.
Investigators: A/Prof A McCluskey; Dr MC Bowyer; Dr CI Holdsworth; Dr CJ Lennard

Title: Assembly and Interactions of Helical Supramolecular Structures
Description: Spontaneously self-assembly of large polynuclear structures, of which polymetallic helical assemblies (helicates) are a significant type, is an intriguing phenomenon that we seek to understand. Elucidating processes involved, important in developing predictive molecular design capabilities, will result from detailed investigation of the rates and strengths of the complex multicomponent interactions of small molecules of restricted mobility with metal ions. We will develop a new family of amidoimine helicates that are chiral, resembling biological helical forms (eg DNA), and possible asymmetric catalysts. We will probe weak outer-sphere interactions of helicates with chiral partners, serving as models for important enzyme-DNA interactions.
Investigators: Prof GA Lawrance; A/Prof M Maeder

Title: Biomarkers of Heavy Metal Stress in Mangrove Ecosystems
Description: A biomarker is a biochemical variation that can be measured in tissue or body fluids of an organism that provides evidence of exposure to and/or effects of chemical pollutants, such as heavy metals. The current study will discover for the first time in a plant model if the 'early-warning' biomarkers of heavy metal stress, peroxidase activity and photosynthetic pigments, reflect not only exposure and biological effect, but are linked and thus predictive of ecological effects for the maintenance of mangrove ecosystems.
Investigators: Dr GR MacFarlane

Title: Polar Cap Region Boundary Dynamics
Description: The Earth's magnetosphere - a dynamic region of near-Earth space - is intermittently disrupted by system-wide, energy release events called substorms that are analogous to earthquakes and important for space weather. Magnetic reconnection in the magnetotail couples this energy release to the high latitude ionosphere. This project will combine multi-instrument observations of the night side ionospheric polar cap boundary with a novel numerical model. The combined modelling/observation approach will provide a unique opportunity to quantify the ionospheric response to magnetic reconnection in the magnetospheric tail. This will provide new insight into substorms and their effects.
Investigators: Dr SK Morley

Title: Space-time and time-frequency applications of improper complex processes
Description:
Complex random signals are widely used in many areas of science and engineering, such as communications, electromagnetics, optics, and acoustics. In this project, we will explore applications of an important special class of complex random signals, called improper, in time-frequency analysis and space-time processing. 

It is expected that the results in time-frequency analysis will find broad application in the characterisation and classification of nonstationary signals and time-varying systems (such as communication channels). The results in space-time processing will lead to a significantly improved tradeoff between spectral efficiency and power consumption in mobile communications.
Investigators: Dr P Schreier

Title: Structural analysis and functional inactivation of bacterial transcription complexes
Description: RNA polymerase (RNAP) is an essential enzyme in all living cells. Its catalytic regions are highly conserved in all kingdoms of life indicating a common mode of catalysis. However, additional transcription factors are required to ensure RNAP functions correctly in the cell and these are conserved within, but not between kingdoms. Therefore, the interactions between essential transcription factors and bacterial RNAP represent an excellent target for the development of new antibiotics. We will obtain and use structural information on a bacterial RNAP complexed with the essential transcription factors sigma and NusA to design small molecule inhibitors which will serve as leads for the development of new antibiotics.
Investigators: Dr PJ Lewis; Dr R Griffith; Dr RJ Lewis

Title: Induction of Plant Transfer Cells - Discovering Regulatory Networks
Description: Transfer cells are specialised to support high nutrient fluxes crucial to plant growth and productivity. Their nutrient transport capacity results from high densities of nutrient transporters embedded in cell membranes whose surface areas are amplified by invaginated wall ingrowths. However, little is known about what controls the formation of these specialised cells. Our aim is to discover key molecular events regulating induction of transfer cells. Outcomes will contribute new fundamental knowledge about processes regulating plant cell differentiation, provide high calibre research training for a postdoctoral fellow and two PhD candidates as well as fostering productive collaborations.
Investigators: Prof JW Patrick; Dr DW McCurdy; A/Prof CE Offler

Title: New Signal Transforms for Multimedia Applications
Description: With the explosion of the Internet and wireless technologies, there have been increased demands for digital multimedia such as images and videos. These demands pose great challenges due to the bandwidth constraints of communication channels (e.g., the Internet) and the memory or power constraints of multimedia devices (e.g., PDAs). To address these challenges, this project aims at developing new algorithms for transmission and processing of multimedia. The research is built upon the state-of-the-art signal processing theories, with emphasis on both fundamental theories and practical implementations. The results will lead to substantial improvements over existing multimedia communication and processing systems.
Investigators: Dr L Gan

Title: Fast Decoding for Multi-Input Multi-Output Wireless Communications
Description: The multi-input multi-output (MIMO) technology promises unprecedented throughput for wireless communication systems. However, the high data-rate transmission poses great challenges to the decoder design and implementation. The standard method of optimum decoding suffers from exponential complexity that is clearly impractical even at moderate data rates. This project will meet the challenges by devising new fast decoders for MIMO communication. A link between number theory and coding theory will be sought and exploited. The decoders will achieve the full potential of MIMO at practical complexity, thereby opening up its wide applications to new-generation wireless communications.
Investigators: Mr C Ling

Title: Exploring Internet Induced Changes in Youth Music Consumption
Description: Identifying the various ways in which music is available online; the range of methods through which young people are currently listening to, purchasing or otherwise consuming music; the impact of the internet on their music consumption habits; and their attitudes towards the different methods of music consumption; will lead to an increased understanding of the social, economic and cultural consequences of the availability of online music products, information and services. The results will be distributed via international music and internet conferences, cultural studies journals and the Australian media.
Investigators: Dr M Kibby

Title: Pictures for Operator Algebras: higher rank graphs
Description:
This project is in the area of pure Mathematics. It seeks to expand upon the interplay between Functional Analysis and Symbolic Dynamics. Our innovative visual approach lies in the use of higher-dimensional graphical models for certain C*-algebras and dynamical systems.

 

Many dynamical systems may be modelled by transitions on a graph; however, recent advances show that complicated systems necessitate more sophisticated models. Our approach is to encode the extra degrees of freedom present in many systems by replacing ordinary graphs with higher-dimensional graphs. This project will realise the potential of this approach, and will shed light on the development of, and recognition problems for, higher dimensional Markov structures.
Investigators: Dr DA Pask; Dr AD Sims

Title: The linguistic use of space in Auslan (Australian Sign Language): semantic roles and grammatical relations in three dimensions
Description: Auslan, the sign language used by the deaf community in Australia, uses space in ways that spoken languages are unable to: to establish and maintain referents in discourse, as well as to describe space itself. By surveying the types of space that are used, describing how loci (locations in space) are established and identifying how they assist with the maintenance of grammatical relations our theoretical understanding of Auslan will be enhanced. This will lead to better resources for teaching adult second language learners, interpreters, and children.
Investigators: Ms LA de Beuzeville; A/Prof TA Johnston

Title: Working Together:  Indigenous and Non-indigenous Collaboration in Australian Film and Literature
Description: Questions of inequality, appropriation, ownership and cultural rights recur about Australian films and literature made by Indigenous and non-indigenous collaborators despite ethics protocols. Through comparative and contextual study of cross-cultural films and literature, this project evaluates collaboration in relation to Indigenous practices of production, custodianship and customary ownership, and non-indigenous concepts such as the author and intellectual property.  This project rises to the challenge of providing a foundational study of collaboration in Australian films and literature relevant to cultural policy. The major outcomes will be an expert workshop and a book.
Investigators: Dr NE Wright; Dr TV Davis; Dr B Collins-Gearing

Title: The Interplay of Feedback Control and Digital Communications
Description:
This project conducts interdisciplinary research in two important areas of control and digital communications. In the first area, we consider the control of dynamical systems using feedback communication links. Our research is expected to produce reliable and practical design methods for network-based control and automation. 

In the second area, we apply systems and control theory to stochastic modelling, analysis, and feedback control design of iterative algorithms. Iterative algorithms are a powerful class of decoding and detection systems in digital communications. Our research will produce a new theoretical foundation for these systems and provide faster iterative algorithms for digital communications.
Investigators: Prof M Fu; Dr P Schreier

Title: Construction methods and analysis tools for repeat-accumulate error correction codes
Description: Error correction codes play a crucial role in digital communications technologies delivering essentially error free information transmission over noisy channels. Exciting breakthroughs in the mid 1990's saw a fundamental shift in error correction technologies with the advent of turbo codes, and rediscovery of low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes. Repeat-accumulate (RA) codes are new, promising "turbo-like" codes, offering the transmitter-side simplicity of turbo codes and the decoding power and efficiency of LDPC codes. This project will develop construction methods and analysis tools for RA codes, and in so doing deliver technologies for future digital communications applications from data storage to wireless networks.
Investigators: Dr SJ Johnson

Title: Improved Capacitor Voltage Balance for Multicell Power Electronic Converters Controlled by Spectrally Optimal Modulation
Description: This project will investigate the capacitor voltage balancing properties of Multicell type converters (i.e. Flying Capacitor and Stacked Multicell Converters) when controlled by the harmonically optimal modulation methods. Multicell converters have many advantages for medium voltage high power applications, but the capacitor voltage regulation problem is a significant challenge and a barrier to the wide-spread use of the technology. Key issues include the determination of the natural balancing limits, the design of special balance booster filters, and active regulation methods. The methodology is to develop theoretical and simulation models of the converter, and to build experimental systems to test and validate of the theoretical results.
Investigators: Dr BP McGrath

Title: Structural Origins of the Giant Piezoelectric Effect in Relaxor Ferroelectrics
Description: Piezoelectric materials interconvert electric and mechanical energy in a wide range of industrial, medical and domestic applications. Up to ten times the response of conventional piezoelectric materials (the giant piezoelectric effect, GPE) is available from PZN-PT single crystals. However, further improvement is blocked by poor fundamental understanding of the origins of the GPE. This project will use in-situ temperature change, electric field or applied stress during the recording of very high-resolution neutron diffraction patterns, to map detailed shifts in atomic position underlying the piezoelectric effect. These rigorous crystal structure-property relationships will assist in the development of a predictive piezoelectric theory.
Investigators: A/Prof EH Kisi; Dr JS Forrester; Dr CJ Howard

Title: Advanced Control of Dual-Stage Hard Disk Drives
Description: This project will involve both fundamental and applied research aimed at developing high performance controllers for dual-stage hard disk drive servo systems. The fundamental inquest will capitalize on innovative controller design methodologies for control of flexible structures, and on robust regulator design methodologies for constrained linear systems. When combined with high-performance sensor-less vibration suppression techniques and innovative instrumented driving mechanisms for piezoelectric transducers, this research will result in sophisticated, yet readily implementable controllers for dual-stage hard disk drive servo systems. All controllers will be implemented, and tested, on a dual-stage HDD.
Investigators: A/Prof SO Moheimani

Title: Optimization Based Finite Element Procedures for Geotechnical Applications
Description: Despite the fact that a number of very efficient methods for strength and deformation analysis are available, common geotechnical applications still present major numerical challenges such as nontrivial soil constitutive models, the phenomenon of volumetric locking, efficient modelling of soil-structure interaction, the simulation of contact boundary conditions, and the incorporation of material discontinuities. This project aims to develop a flexible, yet robust framework for dealing with the above issues by formulating incremental elastoplastic analysis problems in terms of mathematical programs. The solution schemes to deal with the resulting optimization problems will be based on recently developed interior point methods.
Investigators: Dr AV Lyamin; Dr K Krabbenhoft

Title: Analysis, Optimization, and Control of Scanning Atomic Force Microscope Micro-Cantilever Probes
Description: Atomic Force Microscopes (AFM's) have been widely used for the characterization and mapping of surfaces on the micro- and nanometer scale. AFM's comprise two key components, the sample scanning mechanism, and sensor probe - a micro-machined cantilever beam, fixed at one end and free at the other. When in close proximity, changes in the beam vibration can be related to the sample topography. This project aims to increase the resolution of AFM images by actively controlling sensor probe dynamics. A microscopic piezoelectric layer will allow the optimization of mechanical probe dynamics to suit a particular sample surface. Significant increases in resolving power can be expected in challenging environments, e.g. Biological samples in liquid.
Investigators: Dr AJ Fleming

Title: New System Identification Techniques Utilising Misspecified Models
Description: System identification is a methodology for the development of a mathematical representation of a dynamical system based on measurements made upon that system. Most real world systems are complex, hence, the construction of models from first principles is an arduous, sometimes, impossible task. Having techniques available to accurately model a system from measurements is extremely important across many disciplines and key technological areas. This project is aimed at developing novel techniques and theoretical support to solve problems in system identification that are currently unresolved or infeasible in terms of computational complexity.
Investigators: Dr JS Welsh

Title: New Approaches for the Estimation of Complex Dynamic System Models
Description:
In engineering, science and economics it is essential to find

equations that describe how quantities relate to

one another.  This is because these equations can be used for prediction

and control of the quantities, or for detection of faults or changes

in the mechanisms that produce them.  Examples are share market

prices, chemical plant purities, and distortion of radio channels.

This project is directed at determining the necessary describing

equations via automated computer based methods.  Given its importance,

there has already been significant international work in this area.

However, this project will employ new techniques in order to address

more sophisticated modelling problems than have previously been

solvable.
Investigators: A/Prof BM Ninness

Title: Self-heating of porous lignocellulosic and coal particles
Description: This project aims to investigate chemical reactions between porous solid fuels and oxygen at temperatures of below 100 oC.  The results obtained from this project will result in improved fundamental understanding of the oxidation of solid fuels at low temperatures, with applications to self-heating, self-ignition and spontaneous fires, in industries processing coal, wood chips, bagasse, milk powder and other solid fuels.  Expected outcomes from this study will involve new experimental and theoretical information, new insight into catalytic and non-catalytic oxidation of porous solid fuels, a validated model of coal pore structure, as well as training of doctorate researchers.
Investigators: Prof BZ Dlugogorski

Title: A high-throughput stable isotope ratio mass spectrometer for water resource management and climate change studies
Description: Better understanding of the climate system is vital to managing Australia's water resources, biodiversity and response to climate change. Increased use of cave speleothems as high-resolution proxy indicators of past climate is not being matched by dedicated instrumentation needed to produce proxy data. Our new mass spectrometer will support low-cost, high-throughput oxygen and carbon isotope analyses, ensuring that Australian speleothem research plays a major national and international role in climate change studies. Applications include the compilation of detailed pre-instrumental rainfall histories from drought-sensitive parts of Australia, and long-term climate variability in the Pacific basin, SE Asia and the North Atlantic.
Investigators: Dr RN Drysdale; Dr ID Goodwin; Dr SW Franks; Dr JD Woodhead; Dr J Zhao

Title: Advanced technology for transcriptomics, genomics and gene mapping
Description: The aim of this proposal is to introduce the next generation of genome analysis tools to the Universities and Institutions engaged in molecular biological research.  By acquiring the requested equipment the consortium will be able to offer state-of-the art facilities to all researchers who are interested in the molecular basis of variation both in healthy organisms and diseased.  Importantly, the costs of undertaking this type of research will be significantly reduced by the acquistion of the equipment requested.
Investigators: Prof RJ Scott; Prof IW Dawes; Prof RJ Trent; Prof NH Hunt; Prof PL Bergquist; Prof MS Baker; Prof PR Dunkley; Dr R Lin; Prof P Gibson; A/Prof AT Sim

Title: Nano-positioning facility for nano-scale measurement and manipulation
Description: The proposal is aimed at establishing an experimental nanopositioning research facility to enable Australian researchers to undertake nanotechnology research leading to the development of a new generation of nanopositioning systems. Nanopositioners constitute a key component of many devices used in nanotechnology research including atomic force microscopes, scanning tunneling microscopes and near-field scanning optical microscopes. They are also critical to research in areas such as nanoassembly and nanorobotics, metrology, nanobiology, MEMS/NEMS, and probe-based data storage systems. The facility will give Australian nanotechnology researchers an edge in this high-tech and multidisciplinary field.
Investigators: A/Prof SO Moheimani; Prof IR Petersen; Prof GC Goodwin; Prof RH Middleton; Prof M Fu; Dr VA Ougrinovski; A/Prof HR Pota; Dr AJ Fleming; Dr SR Schofield

Title: Advanced Surface and Porosity Characterization Facility
Description: The aim of this facility is to characterize the surface chemistry and porosity of solid materials used in many varied applications such as batteries, heterogeneous catalysis, minerals processing, cement and ceramics. Each of these research fields represents a significant national and international industry, and so successful outcomes using this facility could potentially be of considerable technological as well as economic benefit. The outcomes expected from this facility are in line with the Frontier Technologies -- Advanced Materials priority area of research, in that new and advanced materials with superior performance will be developed and applied to processes within these industries.
Investigators: Dr SW Donne; Prof GA Lawrance; Dr RC Burns; A/Prof EM Kennedy; Prof BZ Dlugogorski; Dr GV Franks; Dr PG Lye; Dr TC Brown; Dr PS Thomas; A/Prof AS Ray

Title: The Rapid Kinetics Research Facility - an Integrated system for rapid kinetic studies of materials using synchrotron radiation
Description: This team will construct the world's first dedicated facility for the real-time study of fast irreversible kinetic processes in advanced materials. The integration of a high throughput X-ray detection system and a comprehensive sample environment coupled to existing synchrotron X-ray sources, will allow the continuous recording of diffraction patterns at time intervals as little as 50 milliseconds. It will enable the study of phenomena such as self-propagating high-temperature synthesis, gel crystallisation, the solidification of melts, and rapid gas-solid phase transitions in unparalleled detail. The facility will be accessible to all Australian researchers through the participation of the Australian Synchrotron Research Program.
Investigators: A/Prof EH Kisi; Dr C Curfs; Dr DP Riley; A/Prof BV King; Prof Dr T Maschmeyer; A/Prof EM Gray; Dr RF Garrett; Mr I Madsen; Dr SA Schmid

Title: Nanostructure Deposition Facility
Description: Nanotechnology is one of the most rapidly developing research areas in Australia and yet facilities for nanofabrication are extremely limited. The Nanostructure Deposition Facility (NDF) is a unique facility, providing access to the highly specialised deposition equipment required to fabricate nanostructured surfaces from a variety of materials. These surfaces are in high demand by researchers from a range of disciplines who wish to exploit their unique material and electronic properties for a variety of applications. The NDF represents a major new joint venture between seven Australian institutions supporting research in areas such as organic electronics, atom optics, biotechnology and nanotechnology.
Investigators: Dr PC Dastoor; Prof J O'Connor; Dr EJ Wanless; Dr MW Radny; Prof RN Lamb; Dr P Meredith; A/Prof MJ Ford; Dr GE Gadd; Dr PJ Evans; Prof GG Wallace; Dr PC Innis; Dr AI Minett; Dr JR Reimers; Prof MJ Crossley; Em/Prof NS Hush; Dr K Ostrikov; Prof DR McKenzie

Title: Ehanced Hydrodynamic Fractionation of Particles
Description: The project aims to apply three complimentary separation mechanisms, fluidization, jigging, and magnetic forces to maximize the tendency of particles of widely varying size and density to fractionate on the basis of their density. The coal industry uses heavy organic liquids in the laboratory to fractionate, known as washability analysis. The liquids are a health risk, hence the industry has timetabled the withdrawal of the existing standard, and needs to establish an alternative urgently.  The study is expected to result in a new water-based method for coal washability analysis. An improved understanding of the segregation and dispersion of particles is also expected, along with novel separation technologies.
Investigators: A/Prof KP Galvin

Title: Smart Utilisation of Thermal Mass in Masonry Buildings
Description: The aim of this project is to evaluate the effectiveness of three innovative concepts by which the thermal mass can be utilised more effectively for regulation of heat in masonry buildings. These are: the hybrid wall, the optimisation of masonry unit geometry, and thermal mass management concepts. The ultimate goal is to improve our current understanding of the effectiveness of these concepts, either in isolation or in combination, and help develop smarter strategies for using the thermal mass as a heat regulator in masonry buildings. The scope of the work, however, is limited to residential buildings although many of our findings are anticipated to be equally applicable to other types of masonry structures.
Investigators: A/Prof B Moghtaderi; Prof AW Page; Ms CM Inglis

Title: Titanium Electrochemistry in Minerals Processing
Description: Production of titanium dioxide pigment using the Sulfate Process is an important Australian industry since we are one of the world's largest producers of titanium containing ores (ilmenite). An important purification step in this process involves generation of a reduced titanium species via the addition of scrap iron, which is both economically and environmentally unfavourable. In this project we will investigate the on-line electrochemical generation of the reduced titanium species, which has the potential to avoid these economic and environmental problems. Outcomes from this work will include a fundamental and applied understanding of soluble titanium redox chemistry, as well as considerable input into an commercial system.
Investigators: Dr SW Donne

Title: Advancing the Ecological Footprint for Application to Policy Development
Description: To achieve Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) humanity must not consume more resources than the planet can supply. The Ecological Footprint (EF) is an indicator that is widely used to assess a population's resource use but which is currently limited in its ability to determine how to most effectively reduce it. This research will advance the capacity of the EF so that it can be used to systematically compare alternative policies relating to ESD. Such a quantum leap in the ability of environmental managers to implement a sustainable society will better protect the resources upon which Australia's environment and economy rely in the short and long-term.
Investigators: Dr V Lauck; Dr M Lenzen; Dr M Wackernagel; Dr GA Albrecht

Title: Stochastic Modelling of Strength and Reliability of Masonry Walls Loaded in Flexure and Compression
Description: Approximately $4 billion is spent on masonry construction in Australia each year. The Clay Brick and Paver Institute (CBPI) believes the current design specifications for structural masonry are conservative (and less competitive on a cost basis with other structural materials). The project will develop new methods to accurately predict wall capacities and calculate structural reliabilities for masonry walls that consider model, load and material spatial variability. A comparison of reliabilities will show which design criteria are inconsistent and improvements can be suggested to ensure adequate and consistent levels of safety. This will help increase the competitiveness of the masonry industry.
Investigators: Prof MG Stewart; Dr MJ Masia; Prof AW Page; Dr SJ Lawrence

Title: Intelligent archiving and retrieving of clinic laboratory records in pathology/radiology informatics study
Description: Since 80% of the critical decisions made in medicine involve a pathology test or radiology examination, Pathology/radiology Informatics has emerged as an arm for developing next-generation pathology/radiology reporting methods, databases, imagery, and diagnostics. Current archiving systems are very primitive, restricting any sophisticated use of the reports. This proposal aims to collaborate with IntelliRAD in developing an innovative pathology/radiology report archiving system capable of automatically extracting useful information. This system will make a smart use of pathology/radiology data and open a new way to extend current tests and examinations from being disease-focussed to being wellness focussed.
Investigators: Prof JS Jin; Prof JE Aisbett; Mr D Burton; Dr R Hofstetter; Dr M Park

Title: Variation and Perceptual Ecologies in Computer Games and Simulations: Towards a Generic Model of Variable 3D Environments
Description: The possibilities and potentials of generic runtime construction of 3D environments will be examined with a focus on the social acceptance of the degree of variability. This will lead to a generic model of variable 3D environments encompassing the full ecology of the user experience. This will include, not only aspects of the terrain and objects within the environment, but also path and spatial attributes to allow for player or unit movement and actions eg hide and special object characteristics that allow for object interaction. The outcomes of this research will be important to game and simulation designers in the design and construction of applications that will immerse the user in a rich and challenging environment.
Investigators: Prof JS Jin; Dr RD Herbert; Dr S Luo

Title: Two-scale modelling of geomaterials
Description: The ability to predict the response of soils and rocks under various loading conditions is of major importance in civil engineering design. The traditional models for these materials are usually based on experimental observation at scales much larger than their microstructures. As such, they are very complex and require extensive experimental data to tune various model parameters. This project aims to develop a fully coupled micro-macro two-scale computational model for geomaterials, in which the macroscopic material behaviour is based on detailed modelling of the microstructure. The resulting model will improve the quality of engineering analysis and hence leads to more efficient and effective engineering design.
Investigators: Dr D Sheng; Prof X Li

Title: Totally disconnected groups, representations and discrete mathematics
Description: Links that have been identified in recent years between the distinct research areas of Lie groups and discrete mathematics have led to innovations in information technology. This project aims to establish new links between these areas and my work on totally disconnected groups. Communication barriers between the distinct fields will be broken down and collaborations initiated which use the group concepts to tackle problems in discrete mathematics. Advances will be made in the theory of totally disconnected groups and in discrete mathematics. Discrete mathematics problems solved may lead to further innovations in information technology.
Investigators: Dr GA Willis; Dr L Carbone

Title: The structure of quantum groups
Description: Complex mathematical problems arising in sciences and engineering can often be given simple solutions if a suitable symmetry is found. Symmetries are mathematically captured through the concept of a group. However, modern quantum theories require that the groups themselves be modified. The recently found modification is called quantum group. In this project, we propose to investigate the internal structure of the most important classes of quantum groups. This will likely lead to immediate applications in the related areas of mathematics, like noncommutative geometry, and theoretical physics, like quantum field theory.
Investigators: Dr W Szymanski; Prof JH Hong

Title: A Theory to Predict and Control Porosity Occurring During Diffusion-Bonding
Description: Already used in the microelectronics and aerospace industries, diffusion-bonding is a recent and attractive process for the strong bonding of dissimilar engineering materials to form devices and structures. However, because of differing diffusion rates of the components, porosity often forms in the bonding zone during fabrication or in-service. This results in a substantial loss of bond strength that is limiting the uptake of this bonding process to other industries. Based on new research on fundamental principles of inter-diffusion, this Project will develop a robust and versatile theory that will predict the onset and extent of porosity formed during diffusion-bonding and will also guide methods for its control.
Investigators: Prof IV Belova

Title: Microgel thin films for controlled release
Description: A key to the advancement of frontier material technologies is the design of functional coatings. Biotechnological examples include control of host-implant responses. The aim here is to develop a series of novel coatings using film-forming polymeric microgel particles. These coatings are expected to swell upon the application of an environmental stimulus (e.g. pH change). The anticipated advantage of microgel thin films over alternative polymeric coatings is the reversible swelling with a substantial volume change and hence loading capacity. Active molecule capture and release will be controlled through the film swelling and hydrophobicity. Potential applications of such ?smart? coatings include delivery devices for drugs and cosmetics.
Investigators: Dr EJ Wanless; Prof SP Armes

Title: Geometric representation of small-rank totally disconnected groups
Description: Totally disconnected groups describe the symmetries of networks and other structures. They are defined abstractly but we aim to give a concrete representation of each such group as the symmetry group of a network constructed from the group. This aim is made feasible by the recent discovery of the rank of a totally disconnected group by one of the investigators. A concrete representation will make the groups easier to work with in the various contexts in which they arise. One of these contexts is the notion of expanders, which are important in computer science, and we will apply our results to obtain new expanders.
Investigators: Dr GA Willis; Dr J Ramagge

Title: Plant Transfer Cells - Discovering the Mechanisms of Wall Ingrowth Formation
Description: Transfer cells form at nutrient transport bottlenecks in plants where high nutrient fluxes are crucial to maintain plant growth. They have specialized invaginated wall ingrowths which amplify the area of the cell's bounding membrane and, in so doing, enhance transport of nutrients into and from cells. Currently our understanding of these unique wall ingrowths is poor despite their significant role in nutrient transport. This project will use proteomics and innovative cell biology procedures to discover key proteins driving the initiation and construction of wall ingrowths. Outcomes will contribute new fundamental knowledge about plant cell differentiation processes and high calibre research training for an APD and a postgraduate student.
Investigators: A/Prof CE Offler; Dr DW McCurdy; Mr MJ Talbot

Title: Verbs and coverbs: a cross-linguistic re-analysis of part-of-speech categories
Description: This ground-breaking project challenges the adequacy of the category 'verb', which has been central to theories of language since Aristotle. Categories like 'verb' and 'noun' are based chiefly on data from European languages. Using new data from Australian and African languages, we will show that significant revisions are required to the classification of words into parts-of-speech. This project will significantly enhance Australia's reputation for major new developments in linguistic theory, based on detailed linguistic fieldwork. It will centrally involve detailed documentation of three endangered Australian languages.
Investigators: Dr MD Harvey; Dr M Amberber; Dr BJ Baker

Title: INVESTIGATION OF A BRAIN RHYTHM
Description: The brain is arguably the most rhythmic organ in the body exhibiting an extraordinary range of electrical rhythms. However, despite these being fundamental to life there is astonishingly little known about brain rhythms. Our studies on cellular pacemaking have uncovered a novel rhythm, which arises through oscillatory release of calcium ions (Ca2+) from intracellular Ca2+ stores and which we term Ca2+ store pacemaking. While, this mechanism was discovered in a smooth muscle, we hypothesise that the same mechanism will function in the Locus Coereleus, a highly rhythmic brain nucleus that is proposed to be involved in establishing mood states. Proof of this hypothesis would be a major advance in our understanding this class of brain rhythm.
Investigators: A/Prof DF van Helden; Dr RJ Callister; Dr AM Brichta

Title: Culture Circuits: Exploring the International Networks and Institutions Shaping Contemporary Cultural Policy
Description: Cultural Policy is expected to achieve an ever-expanding range of social, aesthetic, economic and cultural objectives. This Project explore this agenda and the factors shaping it in four, historically connected countries - Australia, America, Britain and Canada. Specifically, the study tests the proposition that national cultural policy frameworks are increasingly being informed by inter- and supranational exchanges of ideas, personnel, principles and strategies. This task requires evaluating the influences of key nation-to-nation exchanges and the less obvious roles of suprastate bodies like UNESCO. The Project contributes to international debates concerning the formation of national cultural policy priorities and practices.
Investigators: Dr DM Stevenson; A/Prof DC Rowe

Title: The role of sulphate reducing bacteria in the pitting corrosion of mild steel as used for engineering infrastructure applications
Description: This project considers how sulphate reducing bacteria (SRB), found, for example in seawater and in soils, influence the corrosion of mild steel, one of the most common and relatively economical construction materials used in advanced industrial societies. The importance of SRB has been known for a long time but the actual effects on the mechanisms of corrosion are much less understood. This project is particularly interested in how SRB affect the rate of corrosion penetration (or pitting) through steel. This is important for the long-term durability of containment and transport systems including pipelines, nuclear waste systems and ships.
Investigators: Mr R Jeffrey

Title: Frontiers of Labour: Identity and Belonging in Australian Mining and Industrial Towns, 1850-2000
Description: This project represents the first systematic historical study of an Australia-wide sample of mining and industrial towns. Using oral and written sources it aims to study historical patterns of exclusion and inclusion around the fault lines of class, gender, ethnicity and place. Mining and industrial towns generated wealth, employment and distinctive societies. Scattered studies have examined historical and sociological dimensions of individual localities, but there remains no overarching synthesis. New knowledge, including a book publication, will enrich our understanding of the historical diversity of regional Australia, filling in the historical spaces between the ?city? and the ?bush?.
Investigators: Dr EC Eklund

Title: Investigating a New Explanation of Discrimination Against Migrant and Excluded People
Description: One of the most pressing problems facing multicultural societies is the discrimination and prejudice shown against migrant and socially excluded people. In our research, we aim to investigate a new and integrative explanation of this pernicious form of behaviour. To test our explanation, we will conduct a series of psychology experiments that examine how personality and situational factors influence people?s responses to migrant and excluded stimuli in both social and non-social contexts. Our research will provide important information about when and why people discriminate against migrant and excluded individuals as well as how this type of behaviour can be reduced.
Investigators: Dr M Rubin; Dr S Paolini; Dr RJ Crisp

Title: Risk Assessment and Mitigation of Blast Damage to Structural Systems
Description: Blast damage from terrorist attacks on buildings can be extensive, i.e. lives lost, economic damages, social disruption. The aim of the proposed project is to develop a risk-based approach to assessing and mitigating the effects of blast damage to building facades. The risk-based approach is based on probability and structural reliability theory which includes uncertainties and variabilities of loading and structural response prediction models to produce the likelihood and extent of damage. This provides an improved measure of performance that will be incorporated into a life-cycle cost decision analysis framework to determine optimal protective measures for new and existing buildings.
Investigators: A/Prof MG Stewart

Title: Carbon, nutrient and sediment dynamics in a semi-arid catchment
Description: It is important to understand the hydrological and biogeochemical nature of carbon dynamics in catchments so that the carbon flux to streams, rivers and finally the oceans can be quantified. To do this we need to understand the controlling mechanisms of carbon transfer of the soil-vegetation system and the hydrological processes that transport carbon through the stream network. This research proposal will quantify carbon, nutrient and sediment dynamics in a semi-arid climate in the Goulburn River catchment in New South Wales. The results will provide fundamental data in this highly agriculturally productive region allowing better management decisions to be made.
Investigators: Dr GR Hancock; Prof JD Kalma; Prof JJ McDonnell

Title: Particle classification using a ferrofluid in a non uniform magnetic field
Description: In biotechnology, or even mineral processing, there are significant benefits in separating particles on the basis of size and density. With micron size particles, this is an intractable problem. In this innovative study, the forces on non-magnetic particles arising from the magnetization of a ferrofluid will be investigated, the aim being to achieve a two dimensional classification of the particles. The focus of the research will be on the measurement of long-range attractive and repulsive forces between the non-magnetic particles, as these are expected to limit the quality of any separation. These measurements will be used to establish the fundamental understanding needed to develop small-scale diagnostic analytical devices.
Investigators: A/Prof KP Galvin

Title: Handling the 'Battering Ram': Rupert Murdoch, News Corporation and the Global Contest for Dominance in Sports Television
Description: Televised sport, especially involving designated events of ?national cultural significance? like the Olympics, is subject both to intense commercial competition and debate over ownership, access and regulation. Rupert Murdoch?s Newscorp, the most powerful force in world TV sport, has explicitly used sport as a ?battering ram? to develop a global broadcasting operation. This Project will enhance the social scientific understanding of the economic, political and cultural power of global media organisations through a case study of Newscorp?s role in TV sports broadcasting. Anticipated outcomes include conceptual advances and a significant contribution to academic and public debates concerning media, globalisation and national cultures.
Investigators: A/Prof DC Rowe

Title: Muslims and Christians: Women, Religious Nationalism and Sustainability in the Asia Pacific Region.
Description: Through ethnographic studies of minority women in mixed Muslim-Christian communities in Bangladesh, the Philippines and Australia, the project investigates the impact of new "religious nationalisms" on women's behaviour as a boundary marker of religious identity at local, national and international levels. It studies changes in areas of religious life linked to the sustainability of family and community, often the responsibility of women and increasingly marginalized within Asian communities by new global religious forms. The project will advance an understanding of women's responses to these changes and the consequences for the sustainability of communities.
Investigators: Dr ST Rozario; Prof GB Samuel; Asst Prof HM Carey

Title: FRICTION AND CONTACT IN SOIL-STRUCTURE INTERACTION AT LARGE DEFORMATION
Description: Loads are transferred between structures and soils principally through contact of surfaces. The ability to predict the response of soil-structure interfaces is therefore of major importance in civil engineering design, but is complicated by the fact that these interfaces often involve large relative deformation, surface separation and closure. This project aims to formulate and implement new computational tools for predicting the load-deformation behaviour of soil-structure systems that involve large deformation. The computational tools, aimed at practising engineers, will be extremely useful in design of pile foundations, anchors, soil reinforcements and geotechnical testing devices.
Investigators: Dr D Sheng

Title: Operator algebras associated to product systems, and higher-rank-graph algebras
Description: Operator algebras are a tool used in sciences like quantum physics and electrical engineering to describe and study real-world situations. The project will study the operator algebras associated to two mathematical structures: higher-rank graphs, and product systems. The project will investigate to what extent we can think of these sorts of operator algebras as prototypes for the operator algebras used in physical models, and show how to decide what characteristics an operator algebra exhibits just by looking at the higher-rank graph or product system from which it is built.
Investigators: Mr AD Sims

Title: Silicon-based molecular electronics
Description: This project will investigate the physics of constructing electronic devices by positioning individual organic molecules on silicon using a scanning tunnelling microscope (STM).
